sen.j: 足利義持の代となると、義持の後援した田楽の名手増阿弥と人気を争う一方で、『高砂 (能)』『忠度』『清経』『西行桜』『井筒 (能)』『江口 (能)』『桜川 (能)』『蘆刈』『融』『砧 (能)』『恋重荷』などの能を新作した。
sen.e: In the era of Yoshimochi Ashikaga, while he competed with Zoami, the master of Dengaku supported by Yoshimochi for the popularity, he wrote new Noh play such as "Takasago," "Tadanori," "Kiyotsune," "Saigyozakura," "Izutsu (Noh play)," "Eguchi (Noh play)," "Sakuragawa (Noh play)," "Ashikari," "Toru," "Kinuta (Noh play)" and "Koi no Omoni (The Burden of Love)."

Meanwhile, he wrote extravagant and easy-to understand works of Noh such as "Yukiyanagi," "Momijigari (Noh)," "Funa Benkei" whose main themes are miraculous virtue, vengeful spirits and mysteries and he became very popular at that time.

sen.j: この傾向は同じく脇の仕手を勤めた子長俊にも受けつがれ、『正尊』『江野島』などより視覚に訴える平明な作が多く作られた。
sen.e: Such tendency was succeeded by Nagatoshi (Nobumitsu's son) who also acted as waki no shite and wrote many plain works that appealed to the eye including "Shozon" and "Enoshima."

sen.j: 七世観世宗節（1509年〜1583年）は十四歳で父を失った後、長俊の後見によって成長し、1571年ごろから徳川家康に伺候するようになった。
sen.e: After Sosetsu KANZE, the seventh (1509-1583), lost his father when he was fourteen, he grew under the tutelage of Nagatoshi, and began to wait upon Ieyasu TOKUGAWA around 1571.

sen.e: He is known for his active copying densho (books on esoterica), utai-bon (singing texts) and kata tsuke (choreography) in odor to restore the influence of his school of Noh which had a little declined after the death of his last predecessor Nagatoshi.

sen.j: 後代にその名を冠する書物が多く伝わっている。

sen.e: However, later on until the end of the Edo Period the Gokenya and the family of Kuroemon KATAYAMA who served as the Noh players in the Imperial Palace led Kanze school in Kyoto, and formed a school called 'Kyokanze (the Kanze school in Kyoto).

sen.e: Kosetsu KANZE of the branch family (the fifth of the branch family, a great-grandson of Kiyooki) and Minoru UMEWAKA recognized as the head Tsure of Kanze-ryu came to keep Kanze-ryu in Tokyo.

sen.j: 明治初年の衰微期を経て、1876年の岩倉具視邸天覧能以後、徐々に人気を回復しはじめた能楽界にあって梅若実は紅雪とともに観世流の普及につとめた。
sen.e: Through the declining period of 1868, after the Noh play (performed) with Emperor in attendance at the residence of Tomomi IWAKURA in 1876, Minoru UMEWAKA and Kosetsu put efforts to develop the Kanze-ryu in the field of Noh that was beginning to restore its popularity.

sen.j: ついには玄人・素人の弟子に対して梅若の名によって流儀の免状を発行するに至った。

sen.e: However, with the overwhelming authority of Minoru UMEWAKA who was called one of 'three masters in Meiji' with Kuro HOSHO and Banma SAKURAMA, Kiyotaka who retuned to Tokyo did not have the power to control Umewaka family.

sen.j: 清孝の跡を襲った二十三世清廉には後嗣がなく、京都の片山家から養子に入った左近元滋が相続して二十四世宗家となった。
sen.e: Kiyokado, the 23rd who succeeded the position from Kiyotaka did not have a successor, so Sakon Motoshige who had been adopted from the Katayama family in Kyoto succeeded the position and became the 24th soke (the grand master) of Kanze-ryu.

sen.j: 最終的に1921年、梅若実・梅若万三郎の兄弟及び分家六世観世華雪が独立して梅若流を創設するに至る。
sen.e: Finally in 1921, the brothers Minoru UMEWAKA and Manaburo UMEWAKA and Kasetsu KANZE became independent from Kanze-ryu and established Umewaka-ryu.

sen.e: As otsuzumi had derived from rencho (a play performed by utai and a single percussion instrument in combination) of kotsuzumi, its independence was later than other hayashi kata (musician in Noh) groups.

sen.j: 1694年、宝生流を好んだ徳川綱吉の命により宝生座座付を命ぜられ、家元家も姓を「宝生」に改めた。
sen.e: In 1694, it was ordered by Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA who favored Hosho-ryu to work in Hosho-za, and it changed its family name to 'HOSHO.'

sen.j: ただし三世・宝生信春が後嗣を欠いたときには、観世流小鼓方十三世観世豊綿の三男錬三郎豊羨が養子入する。
sen.e: But in the case that Nobuharu HOSHO did not have his successor, Renzaburo 豊羨, the third son of Kanze-ryu kotsuzumi-kata 豊綿 KANZE, the 13th was adopted into the family.

sen.j: 以上のような事情により、維新後は長らく一流と認められず、「大鼓方宝生錬三郎派」とされてきた。
sen.e: With the circumstances mentioned above, it was not recognized as a school and called 'otsuzumi-kata Hosho-ryu of Renzaburo school' for a long time after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: シテ方観世流三世音阿弥の子・観世与四郎吉国（1440年〜1493年）が、金春流太鼓方の流祖金春豊氏の弟子となって流儀を興した。
sen.e: Yoshiro Yoshikuni KANZE (1440-1493), the son of shite-kata Kanze-ryu Otoami, apprenticed himself to Harutoyo KONPARU, the founder of Konparu-ryu taiko-kata, and founded the school.
